```{r,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE,eval=TRUE,include=FALSE}

# packages we will use in the course
pac <- c("moments", "sandwich", "lmtest", "car", "plm", "ivreg", "dynlm", "forecast", "urca")

# install and/or load packages
checkpac <- function(x) {
  if (!require(x, character.only = TRUE)) {
    install.packages(x)
  }
  require(x, character.only = TRUE)
}

# check if packages are install yet
suppressWarnings(sapply(pac, checkpac))

```

## Data Set {.tabset .tabset-fade}

<!-- The data set `Assignment_data_2223.txt` contains observations about individuals in the U.S for the years 2006 to 2012. -->

<!-- The data set `Assignment_data_2324.txt` contains observations about counties in the North Caroline (USA) for the years 81 to 87. -->

The data set `Assignment_data_2324.txt` contains observations about US counties for the years 2000 to 2006.

Download the data sets from *ILIAS* directly or by using the link below:

<!-- <p class="down01"> -->
<!-- <a id="download-data-id" href="#" download="Assignment_data_2324.txt" onclick="downloadDataSet('Assignment_data_2324.txt')">Download `Assignment_data_2324.txt`</a> -->
<!-- </p> -->

<p class="down01">
<a id="download-data-id" href="#" download="Assignment_data_2324.txt" onclick="downloadDataSet('./data-sets/Assignment_data_2324.txt')">Download `Assignment_data_2324.txt`</a>
</p>

The variables in the data set are:

| Variable    | Description                      | 
|:-----------:|:---------------------------------| 
|	$year$ | Year |
|	$id$ | County ID |
|	$y_{it}$ | Crime rate |
|	$x_{1it}$ | Probability of arrest |
|	$x_{2it}$ | Probability of conviction |
|	$x_{3it}$ | Probability of prison sentence |
|	$x_{4it}$ | Average prison sentence |
|	$x_{5it}$ | Proportion of young men |
|	$x_{6it}$ | Average weekly wage in manufacturing sector |
|	$d_{1it}$ | 1 if urban county, 0 otherwise |

<!-- lcrmrte ~ lprbarr + lprbconv + lprbpris + avgsen +  pctymle + urban + wmfg -->

<!--..........................................................................-->

The purpose of the analysis is to explain the relationship between crime and punishment.

## Task 2 {.tabset .tabset-fade}

<!-- <hr /> -->

<p class="head01">
Task 2
</p>

Use all observation *2000-2006* pooled together and consider the following *regression model*:

\begin{align*}
\small
ln\left(y_{it}\right) = \beta_{1} ln\left(x_{1it}\right) + \beta_{2} ln\left(x_{2it}\right) + \beta_{3} ln\left(x_{3it}\right) + \beta_4 x_{4it} + \beta_5 x_{5it} + \beta_6 ln\left(x_{6it}\right) + \beta_7 d_{1it} + u_{it} \; (1)
\end{align*}





<hr />

<!--..........................................................................-->
### Task a) 

Estimate regression model (1) by OLS. Interpret the estimated coefficients for the variables \(x_1\), \(x_6\) and \(d_1\).

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Estimation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible01"> *Show Code* </button>
<div class="cod_content">
```{r,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE,results=FALSE,fig.show='hide'}

# Estimate linear regression model
lm.res.01 <- lm_ct_fun(log(y) ~ log(x1) + log(x2) + log(x3) + x4 + x5 + log(x6) + d1, data = dat.all, hc.type = "HC1")
lm.res.01$ct

```
</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible01"> *Show Output* </button>
<div class="cod_content">
```{r,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE,results=TRUE}

# Estimate linear regression model
lm.res.01 <- lm_ct_fun(log(y) ~ log(x1) + log(x2) + log(x3) + x4 + x5 + log(x6) + d1, data = dat.all, hc.type = "HC1")
lm.res.01$ct

```
</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Interpretation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Interpretation* </button>
<div class="col_content">

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

* $x_1$:
  * An increase of the probability of arrest by one percent decreases the crime rate by $0.562$ \% after holding the other variables constant.
  * Effect is statistically significant at any common significance level.
  * Large effect(?) but expected sign. 
* $x_6$:
  * An increase of the average weekly wage in manufacturing sector by one percent increases the crime rate by $0.190$ \% after holding the other variables constant.
  * Effect is statistically significant at five percent significance level.
  * Unexpected sign.
* $d_1$:
  * In urban counties the crime rate is by $43.642$ \% higher than in non-urban counties after holding the other variables constant.
  * Effect is statistically significant at any common significance level.
  * Expected sign.

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

*Add your Interpretation here!*

</div>

</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->





<!--..........................................................................-->

</p>

</div>

<!--..........................................................................-->
### Task c) 

Test the hypothesis, that an increase of the <em>probability of arrest</em> by \(1\%\) decreases the <em>crime rate</em> by \(0.5\%\). State the null hypothesis, calculate the test statistic and calculate the <em>p</em>-value. Interpret your result.

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Estimation Results
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible01"> *Show Results* </button>
<div class="cod_content">
```{r,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE,results=TRUE}

# Estimate linear regression model
lm.res.01 <- lm_ct_fun(log(y) ~ log(x1) + log(x2) + log(x3) + x4 + x5 + log(x6) + d1, data = dat.all, hc.type = "HC1" )
lm.res.01$ct

```
</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Interpretation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Statement of hypothesis* </button>
<div class="col_content">

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

<hr />

<p class="head03">
General (for slope parameter)
</p>

\begin{align}
H_0&: \quad \beta_{1} = \beta_{1,0} \quad \text{vs.} \\
H_1&: \quad \beta_{1} \neq \beta_{1,0} \quad \alpha = 5\%
\end{align}

<hr />

<p class="head03">
Here
</p>

\begin{align}
H_0&: \quad \beta_{1} = -0.5 \quad \text{vs.} \\
H_1&: \quad \beta_{1} \neq -0.5 \quad \alpha = 5\%
\end{align}

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

*Add your Interpretation here!*

</div>

</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Calculation of test statistic* </button>
<div class="col_content">

```{r,include=FALSE}

ct.rob.01 <- lm.res.01$ct
tes.sta.val.01 <- (round(ct.rob.01[2,1],3)-(-0.5))/round(ct.rob.01[2,2],3)
tes.sta.val.01

```

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

\begin{align}
t^{act} &= \frac{\widehat{\beta}_{1}^{act} - (-0.5)}{SE\left(\widehat{\beta}_{1}\right)} \\
t^{act} &= \frac{`r round(ct.rob.01[2,1],3)` - (-0.5)}{`r round(ct.rob.01[2,2],3)`} \\
t^{act} &= `r round(tes.sta.val.01,3)`
\end{align}

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

*Add your Interpretation here!*

</div>

</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Conclusion based on test statistic* </button>
<div class="col_content">

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

* $|t^{act}| < 1.64$
* $H_0$ cannot be rejected at a 10\% and thus, also not at 5\% significance level.

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

*Add your Interpretation here!*

</div>

</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<!--..........................................................................-->

```{r,include=FALSE}
pval.01 <- 2*pnorm(-abs(round(tes.sta.val.01,3)))
pval.01

```

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

\begin{align}
p-\text{value} &= 2*\Phi\left(-|t^{act}|\right) \\
&= 2*\Phi\left(`r -abs(round(tes.sta.val.01,3))`\right) \\
&= `r format(pval.01,3)`
\end{align}

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

</div>

<!-- *Add your results here!* -->

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

<u>Conclusion</u>:

* $0.10 < p\text{-value}$
* $H_0$ cannot be rejected at a 10\% and thus, also not at 5\% significance level.

<u>Definition $p$-value</u>:

* The p-value is the probability of observing a value of $\hat{\beta}$ at least as different from $\beta_{1,0}$ as the estimate actually computed $\left(\hat{\beta}^{act}_1\right)$, assuming that the null hypothesis is correct.
* Type I error, i.e. rejecting $H_0$ even if it is true.

### Task d) 

Test the null hypothesis that the effect of <em>probability of conviction</em> and the effect of <em>probability of prison sentence</em> are equal to zero. State the null hypothesis, calculate the test statistic and calculate the <em>p</em>-value. Interpret your result.

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Test
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible01"> *Show Code* </button>
<div class="cod_content">
```{r,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE,results=FALSE,fig.show='hide'}

# heteroskedasticity-robust F-test (all regressors equals zero)
lin.hyp.01 <- linearHypothesis(lm.res.01, c("log(x2)=0",
                                            "log(x3)=0"), white.adjust = "hc1")
lin.hyp.01

```
</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible01"> *Show Output* </button>
<div class="cod_content">
```{r,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE,results=TRUE}

# heteroskedasticity-robust F-test (all regressors equals zero)
lin.hyp.01 <- linearHypothesis(lm.res.01, c("log(x2)=0",
                                            "log(x3)=0"), white.adjust = "hc1")
lin.hyp.01

```
</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Interpretation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Interpretation* </button>
<div class="col_content">

<p class="head01">
Hypothesis
</p>

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

\begin{align}
H_0&: \quad \beta_{1} = \beta_{2} = 0 \quad \text{vs.} \\
H_1&: \quad \text{at least one} \neq 0 \quad \quad \alpha = 5\%
\end{align}

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

<p class="sub01">
*Add the hypothesis here!*
</p>

</div>

<p class="head01">
Test statistic
</p>

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

\begin{align}
F^{act}\left( `r lin.hyp.01$Df[2]`, `r lin.hyp.01$Res.Df[2]` \right) &= `r round(lin.hyp.01$F[2],3)`
\end{align}

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

<p class="sub01">
*Add the test statistic here!*
</p>

</div>

<p class="head01">
$p$-value
</p>

```{r}
pval <- round(lin.hyp.01$`Pr(>F)`[2],3)
```

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

\begin{align}
p-\text{value} &= Pr\left[ F\left( `r lin.hyp.01$Df[2]`, `r lin.hyp.01$Res.Df[2]` \right) > F^{act}\left( `r lin.hyp.01$Df[2]`, `r lin.hyp.01$Res.Df[2]` \right) \right] \\
p-\text{value} &\approx `r pval`
\end{align}

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

<p class="sub01">
*Add the $p$-value here!*
</p>

</div>

<p class="head01">
Decision
</p>

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

<p class="sub01">

* Rejection of $H_0$ as 

\begin{align}
F^{act}\left( `r lin.hyp.01$Df[2]`, \infty \right) &> F^{crit \, 5\%}\left( `r lin.hyp.01$Df[2]`, \infty \right) \\
F^{act}\left( `r lin.hyp.01$Df[2]`, \infty \right) &> 3.00
\end{align}

* Or, rejection of $H_0$ as $p-\text{value} < 0.05$.

</p>

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

<p class="sub01">
*Add the decision here!*
</p>

</div>

<p class="head01">
Note
</p>

* Check also the asymptotic critical value of the test statistic, i,e, $F\left(2,\infty\right)$, for $\alpha =5\%$.
* Use Table 4 in Stock and Watson (2020) on p. 767. (see below)

</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Critical value for the $\underline{F\left(m,\infty\right)}$
</p>

<p class="head03">

</div>

<hr />

<p class="head03">
Regression estimation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible01"> *Show Code* </button>
<div class="cod_content">
```{r,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE,results=FALSE,fig.show='hide'}
# Estimate auxiliary linear regression model
lm.res.02 <- lm_ct_fun(log(y) ~ log(x1) + log(x3) + x4 + x5 + log(x6) + d1 + W, data = dat.all, hc.type = "HC1")
lm.res.02$ct
```
</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible01"> *Show Output* </button>
<div class="cod_content">
```{r,include=TRUE,echo=FALSE,results=TRUE}

lm.res.02 <- lm_ct_fun(log(y) ~ log(x1) + log(x3) + x4 + x5 + log(x6) + d1 + W, data = dat.all, hc.type = "HC1")
lm.res.02$ct
```
</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<hr />

<p class="head03">
Transformation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Transformation* </button>
<div class="col_content">

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

<div style="font-size: 12pt";>

<!-- \begin{align} -->
<!-- score_{i} &= \beta_{0} + \beta_{STR}STR_{i} + \beta_{PctEL}PctEL_{i} + \beta_{Expn}Expn_{i} + u_{i} \\ -->
<!-- score_{i} &= \beta_{0} + \beta_{STR}STR_{i} + \beta_{PctEL}PctEL_{i} + \beta_{Expn}Expn_{i} + u_{i} \,\,\,\,\, | +\left(\beta_{Expn}STR_{i}-\beta_{Expn}STR_{i}\right)  \\ -->
<!-- score_{i} &= \beta_{0} + \beta_{STR}STR_{i} - \beta_{Expn}STR_{i} + \beta_{PctEL}PctEL_{i} + \beta_{Expn}Expn_{i} + \beta_{Expn}STR_{i} + u_{i} \\ -->
<!-- score_{i} &= \beta_{0} + \left(\beta_{STR} - \beta_{Expn}\right) STR_{i} + \beta_{PctEL}PctEL_{i} + \beta_{Expn} \left(Expn_{i} + STR_{i}\right) + u_{i} \\ -->
<!-- score_{i} &= \beta_{0} + \gamma_{1} STR_{i} + \beta_{PctEL}PctEL_{i} + \beta_{Expn} W_{i} + u_{i} \\ -->
<!-- \end{align} -->

\begin{align}
ln\left(y_{it}\right) &= \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}ln\left(x_{1it}\right) + \beta_{2}ln\left(x_{2it}\right) + ... + u_{i} \\
ln\left(y_{it}\right) &= \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}ln\left(x_{1it}\right) + \beta_{2}ln\left(x_{2it}\right) + ... + u_{i} \,\,\,\,\, | +\left(\beta_{2}ln\left(x_{1it}\right)-\beta_{2}ln\left(x_{1it}\right)\right)  \\
ln\left(y_{it}\right) &= \beta_{0} + \left(\beta_{1} - \beta_{2}\right) ln\left(x_{1it}\right) + \beta_{2} \left(ln\left(x_{1it}\right) + ln\left(x_{2it}\right)\right) + ... + u_{i} \\
ln\left(y_{it}\right) &= \beta_{0} + \gamma_{1} ln\left(x_{1it}\right) + \beta_{2} W_{i} + ... + u_{i} \\
\end{align}

</div>

with

\begin{align}
\gamma_{1} \equiv \beta_{1} - \beta_{2} \\
W \equiv ln\left(x_{1it}\right) + ln\left(x_{2it}\right)
\end{align}

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

*Add your results here!*

</div>


</div>

<hr />

<p class="head03">
Interpretation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Statement of hypothesis* </button>
<div class="col_content">

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

\begin{align}
H_0&: \quad \beta_{1} - \beta_{2} = 0 \\
H_0&: \quad \gamma_{1} = 0 \quad \text{vs.} \\
H_1&: \quad \gamma_{1} \neq 0 \quad \alpha = 5\%
\end{align}

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

*Add your results here!*

</div>

</div>

Based on test statistic
</p>

<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Calculation of test statistic* </button>

```{r,include=FALSE}

tes.sta.val

```

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

\begin{align}
t^{act} &= \frac{\hat{\gamma_{1}}^{act} - 0}{SE\left(\hat{\gamma_{1}}\right)} \\
t^{act} &= \frac{`r round(lm.res.02$ct[2,1],3)` - 0}{`r round(lm.res.02$ct[2,2],3)`} \\
t^{act} &= `r round(tes.sta.val,3)`
\end{align}

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

*Add your results here!*

</div>

</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<div class="col_content">

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

<u>Conclusion</u>:

* $|t^{act}| > 1.96$
* $H_0$ can be rejected at 5\%.

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

*Add your results here!*

</div>

</div>

### Task f) 

Discuss the possibility of an omitted variables bias in the regression model (1). What are potential omitted factors?

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Interpretation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Interpretation* </button>
<div class="col_content">

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

<u>Omitted variable bias arises when</u>:

* (1) The omitted variable is correlated with the included regressors, e.g., average weekly wage in manufacturing sector $\left(x_6\right)$, and
* (2) the omitted variable is a determinant of the dependent variable, i.e., crime rate $(y)$.

<u>Potential omitted variables/factor</u>: Police investment

* Richer counties with a higher average weekly wage in manufacturing sector invest more in the police. (see (1))
* More investment in the police results in more detection of crimes and thus, in higher higher crime rate. (see (2))

</div>

<div style="color: red" class="noSol01">

*Add your Interpretation here!*

</div>

</div>

<p class="head01">
Task 3
</p>

Use observations from *all years* and consider the following *fixed effects regression model*:

\begin{align*}
\small
ln\left(y_{it}\right) = \beta_{1} ln\left(x_{1it}\right) + \beta_{2} ln\left(x_{2it}\right) + \beta_{3} ln\left(x_{3it}\right) + \beta_4 x_{4it} + \beta_5 x_{5it} + \beta_6 ln\left(x_{6it}\right) + \alpha_i + u_{it} \; (2)
\end{align*}

<!--..........................................................................-->
### Task a) 

Estimate model (2) by entity specific fixed effects. Compare the estimation results with the estimation results of Task 1.

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Estimation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible01"> *Show Code* </button>

```{r,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE,results=FALSE,fig.show='hide'}
# Estimate panel regression model
plm.res.01 <- plm_ct_fun(log(y) ~ log(x1) + log(x2) + log(x3) + x4 +  x5 + log(x6) + d1,
                         data = dat.all,
                         index = c("id","year"),
                         effect = "individual",
                         model = "within") 

plm.res.01$ct

```
</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible01"> *Show Output* </button>
<div class="cod_content">
```{r,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE,results=TRUE}

# Estimate panel regression model
plm.res.01 <- plm_ct_fun(log(y) ~ log(x1) + log(x2) + log(x3) + x4 +  x5 + log(x6) + d1,
                         data = dat.all,
                         index = c("id","year"),
                         effect = "individual",
                         model = "within") 

plm.res.01$ct

```
</div>
<!--..........................................................................-->

<div class="col_content">

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

* $x_1$:
  * An increase of the probability of arrest by one percent decreases the crime rate by $0.225$ \% after holding the other variables constant.
  * Effect is statistically significant only at ten percent significance level.
  * Smaller effect(?) and expected sign. 
* $x_6$:
  * An increase of the average weekly wage in manufacturing sector by one percent decreases the crime rate by $0.273$ \% after holding the other variables constant.
  * Effect is statistically significant at five percent significance level.
  * Expected sign.
* $d_1$:
  * Effect is not identified but captured by the fixed effect in $\alpha_i$!

</div>

### Task c) 

Compare and discuss the suitability of model (1) of Task 1 vs. model (2) of Task 2 to analyse the relationship crime and punishment.

<hr />

<p class="head02">
Interpretation
</p>

<!--..........................................................................-->
<button type="button" class="collapsible02"> *Interpretation* </button>
<div class="col_content">

<div style="color: red" class="showSol01">

<!-- * The fixed effects regression model (2) is not suitable to analyse the relationship between years of education and wage. -->
<!-- * The effect of one more year of education is not identified in the FE model but is captured by $\alpha_i$.  -->

* The estimated effects, especially for the average weekly wage in manufacturing sector, is different for the pooled model (model 1) and the fixed effect model (model 2).
* The pooled model (model 1) seems to suffer from OVB.
* The fixed effect model (model 2) is more reliable for the analysis of the relationship crime and punishment.
